author: By David E. Sanger
title: Musk Team’s Treasury Access Raises Security Fears, Despite Judge’s Ordered Halt
description: A judge ruled Saturday that the activities of Elon Musk’s government cost-cutting effort risk “the disclosure of sensitive and confidential information” and render them “more vulnerable than before to hacking.”
content: A federal judge’s order that Elon Musk’s team temporarily cease boring into the Treasury Department’s payment systems raises a far larger question: whether what Elon Musk has labeled the Department of Government Efficiency is creating a major cyber and national security vulnerability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,331
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Feb. 9, 2025.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein
title: Trans Youth Are Rattled by Efforts to Ban Gender Care. So Are Hospitals.
description: President Trump’s executive order threatening hospitals’ funding if they provide gender transition care for youth has caused chaos in the transgender health landscape.
content: The Trump administration’s executive order seeking to bar hospitals from providing certain kinds of care for transgender youth has inspired anxiety among parents, at least one lawsuit, and demonstrations by transgender activists and progressive politicians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova
title: How War Has Wreaked Havoc on Ukraine’s Classrooms
description: Students have been forced to attend classes underground or online, especially in regions near the front line. Experts say that Ukrainian children are falling behind as a result, academically and socially.
content: The students meet a day a week for lessons in a tiny underground classroom that teachers call the beehive, for the buzzing of all the children packed inside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robyn Gigl
title: 7 Great Legal Thrillers
description: The novelist Robyn Gigl picks her favorite courtroom dramas and legal whodunits — some of which may surprise you.
content: Since I’ve written four legal thrillers, you won’t be surprised to learn that I also love to read them. I use the term “legal thriller” in the broadest possible sense: courtroom dramas, stories focused on corruption in the legal profession, good old-fashioned legal whodunits. What really draws me in is a novel with a broader social context that lets me see the world from a perspective that’s different from my own. In my own novels, the main protagonist is Erin McCabe — a criminal defense attorney who, like me, also happens to be a transgender woman. I use Erin to introduce readers who may not know anyone who is trans to a character that humanizes the transgender experience and the issues we face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Ian Austen
title: Betrayed: How Trump’s Tariff Threats Tore the U.S.-Canada Bond
description: Patriotic sentiment is bursting in Canada after President Trump’s threat to apply hefty tariffs and even annex the country. The damage to the two nations’ relationship could be lasting.
content: Booing during “The Star-Spangled Banner” at sports games in Canada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: In One of Europe’s Surging Economies, a Strongman Leader Is Feeling the Pinch
description: President Aleksandar Vucic of Serbia, battered by months of nationwide protests, is struggling to weather his biggest political crisis in more than a decade of rule.
content: Serbia’s authoritarian leader should be riding high, lifted by economic growth that is four times the European average, falling unemployment and steadily rising wages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suhasini Raj and Mujib Mashal
title: Modi’s Party Wins Major Victory in Election in India’s Capital Region
description: Control of the assembly in New Delhi is set to change hands, a feat that eluded the Indian prime minister’s Bharatiya Janata Party for nearly three decades.
content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s national governing party has swept to victory in an important regional election in India’s capital, where voters previously rejected Mr. Modi’s Hindu-first platform for nearly three decades even as it expanded its footprint elsewhere across the vast country.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 8, 2025
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Feb. 8, 2025.
content: An article on Friday about efforts by the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform to learn about a project to screen elite Navy fighter pilots for signs of brain injuries caused by flying misstated the month of Capt. William Catlett’s death. It was in December 2024, not January 2025.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Can MAGA Run the American Empire?
description: The real stakes of the U.S.A.I.D. debate.
content: I didn’t expect that the first great struggle of the Trump administration would focus on the United States Agency for International Development. But in hindsight it makes perfect sense, because U.S.A.I.D. sits at the place where the traditional conservative critique of government spending meets the populist critique of professional-class ideology: It’s two battles for the price of one.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Assault on Diversity
description: Readers discuss diversity, equity and inclusion in the military, the government and in corporations.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Connections Companion No. 609
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Feb. 9, 2025.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: Using ‘Three-Peat,’ a Trademarked Sports Phrase, Means Paying for Bragging Rights
description: As sports catchphrases start to stick, savvy coaches and athletes are moving to protect them with federal trademarks. “Three-Peat” is just one of many.
content: The Kansas City Chiefs are aiming to win their third consecutive Super Bowl on Sunday and become the first team to pull off a Super Bowl “three-peat.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Trump and Musk Attack Journalists by Name in Social Media Posts
description: Since his inauguration, the president has been quick to demonize what he calls “the fake news media.” On Friday, both men demanded that individuals be fired.
content: President Trump has made clear his animus toward mainstream media organizations. Now he’s getting more personal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Zerofsky
title: Trump Joins a Global War on ‘Gender Ideology’
description: He’s allying with a movement that stretches to Hungary and Poland — one that looks with skepticism not just on trans rights but on feminism itself.
content: In an executive order dated Jan. 27, President Trump declared that the Department of Defense was renewing its “singular focus on developing the requisite warrior ethos.” That mission, it argued, could not be diluted by accommodating “radical gender ideology” — and therefore transgender people were not qualified to serve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise and Tripp Mickle
title: Microsoft and Nvidia: The Tech Giants Taking a Quieter Approach to Trump
description: Other big technology companies have been boisterous in their courtship of the new administration. But Nvidia and Microsoft have avoided the Washington spotlight.
content: Friday afternoon last week, Jensen Huang, the chief executive of the chipmaker Nvidia, slipped into the White House to meet President Trump for the first time. There was no fanfare, and he left without a single public photo taken of the two.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Robert Jimison
title: Trump Administration Moves to Send $8 Billion in Arms to Israel, Bypassing Some Lawmakers
description: President Biden announced the arms sales at the end of his administration, and President Trump is pushing it soon after his meeting with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.
content: The State Department has given Congress formal notification that it plans to move forward with sales of more than $8 billion in weapons to Israel, bypassing an informal review process that was underway in a House committee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: Amy Lau, Interior Designer and a Founder of Design Miami, Dies at 56
description: Known for her expertise on midcentury modernism and love of Southwestern colors, she also helped create an annual event showcasing the work of other designers.
content: Amy Lau, a New York interior designer and a founder of the annual Design Miami fair, whose vernacular was the saturated colors of the American Southwest and whose deep knowledge of modernist objects was the foundation of her work, died on Jan. 17 in Scottsdale, Ariz. She was 56.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Musk’s Lost Boys and Trump’s Mean Girls
description: Lost boys find ways to ransack the capital.
content: Tom Stoppard wrote in “The Real Thing,” his enticing play about infidelity: “To marry one actress is unfortunate. To marry two is simply asking for it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: Trump Fires Nation’s Archivist in Latest Round of Personnel Purge
description: “No cause or reason was cited,” wrote the archivist, Colleen Shogan. But the National Archives had been deeply involved in the classified documents case against President Trump.
content: The nation’s archivist, Colleen Shogan, said on social media Friday night she had been fired by President Trump, in the latest act of retribution against a perceived foe that the president had promised to deliver upon returning to the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Critics Choice Awards 2025: The Complete Winners List
description: “Anora” scored big in the final minutes of the ceremony, while Demi Moore and Adrien Brody collected the top acting honors at the 30th annual Critics Choice Awards.
content: See all the arrival photos from the 2025 Critics Choice Awards red carpet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn McCreesh
title: Will a Time Magazine Cover Drive a Wedge Between Trump and Musk?
description: The cover of the venerable newsweekly, long an object of fixation for the president, put Elon Musk behind the Resolute Desk.
content: The president did not look amused. He was meeting the Japanese prime minister for the first time on Friday when a reporter shouted out to ask if he had a “reaction” to the new cover of Time magazine. The cover, the reporter told Mr. Trump, depicts “Elon Musk sitting behind your Resolute Desk.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Now Is Not the Time to Tune Out
description: Trump’s presidency demands your attention.
content: Don’t get distracted. Don’t get overwhelmed. Don’t get paralyzed and pulled into the chaos that President Trump and his allies are purposely creating with the volume and speed of executive orders; the effort to dismantle the federal government; the performative attacks on immigrants, transgender people and the very concept of diversity itself; the demands that other countries accept Americans as their new overlords; and the dizzying sense that the White House could do or say anything at any moment. All of this is intended to keep the country on its back heel so President Trump can blaze ahead in his drive for maximum executive power, so no one can stop the audacious, ill-conceived and frequently illegal agenda being advanced by his administration. For goodness sake, don’t tune out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: These Wings Are ‘Finger-Lickin’ Fabulous’
description: A five-star recipe from the chef Rio Irie yields spicy chicken wings that are funky and salty, sweet and sticky.
content: With all due respect to steak and lobster, I think the best surf ‘n’ turf combination is chicken and anchovies. It’s an opposites-attract situation: The chicken is large and plump with a soft-spoken umami; it says: “How nice to meet you. I’m looking forward to working together.” Anchovies, scrawny and electric with salty savoriness, kick in the door, press play on the boombox and say: “I’m here. Let’s do this.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Loudin and Theodore Tae
title: An Effective HIIT Routine for Beginners Short on Time
description: High intensity workouts are a great way to get in some fast exercise. Here’s one to get started with.
content: If you’re looking for an exercise routine that will deliver big returns with a small time investment, consider high intensity interval training, or HIIT. Just two or three 30-minute sessions per week can improve cardiovascular fitness, lower blood pressure and burn more calories than other forms of exercise. It can also improve your performance in sports, because a HIIT workout engages your entire body.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By M. Gessen
title: The Chilling Consequences of Going Along With Trump
description: The voluntarily surrender of the public’s power is how autocracies are built.
content: In 1978, my parents went to Poland, the first foreign trip in each of their lives. When they returned to our home in Moscow, my mother couldn’t stop talking about what they’d seen — not a place but a movie, Bob Fosse’s “Cabaret.” One scene in particular stayed with her. Three friends are returning from a weekend trip. Sleep-deprived, hung over and preoccupied with their sexual and romantic entanglements, they pull over at a roadside cafe. There, a teenager wearing a Hitler Youth uniform starts singing. He is both earnest and, in his brown pants tucked into white knee-high socks, puerile. But after a minute, other young people in uniform join in, and soon all but one customer are standing and singing. The protagonists duck out. They have been pushing Nazism out of their minds, but at this moment they realize that they are in the minority, that life as they’ve been living it is over. The song everyone around them is singing is “Tomorrow Belongs to Me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Far-Right Leaders Rally in Spain to ‘Make Europe Great Again’
description: At a gathering in Madrid, members of Europe’s far-right parties set aside any trepidation they might have about President Trump’s threats and instead focused on a common enemy: the European Union.
content: Since taking office, President Trump has threatened European countries’ security and economies, angled to take control of Greenland and promised to “definitely” slap the nations with tariffs. Even parties that would seem to be his natural allies are nervous. Some have quietly tiptoed back from the American president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Camille Baker
title: How Could the Weather Service Change Under Trump?
description: President Trump tangled with its forecasters during his first term. As he slashes government spending, many wonder what that means for weather data.
content: As President Trump issues rapid-fire executive orders intended to drastically reduce the federal work force and dismantle several agencies, many federal employees are left wondering what the future holds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport and Madeleine Ngo
title: Trump Administration Move to Freeze E.V. Charger Funding Confounds States
description: Some have halted work on the Biden-era $5 billion program to build E.V. charging stations. Others plan to keep building. Most are confused.
content: A new federal order that freezes a Biden-era program to build a national network of electric vehicle charging stations has confounded states, which had been allocated billions of dollars by Congress for the program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: It’s No Secret What Trump and His Allies Mean When They Talk About ‘Shock and Awe’
description: How the war in Iraq helps us understand Trump’s war on the federal government.
content: Americans were supposed to be stunned by the opening salvo of Donald Trump’s second term. In fact, his aides and allies took pains to describe his initial flurry of executive activity as “shock and awe,” reviving an analogy to the 2003 invasion of Iraq, when American troops pounded Saddam Hussein’s army with a fusillade of ordnance as they charged through to Baghdad. And in much the same way that President George W. Bush believed he was cowing America’s enemies with an overwhelming display of military might, Trump believes he is pounding his domestic political enemies into submission. Trump also believes, I imagine, that he and his acolytes will be greeted as liberators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: Why the Odds of an Asteroid Striking Earth in 2032 Keep Going Up (and Down)
description: NASA and European scientists explain how they calculate the probability of the space rock 2024 YR4 impacting our planet, and why it’s not yet time to worry.
content: Since December, astronomers have been carefully studying whether an asteroid between 130 and 300 feet long will impact the Earth in just under eight years. And the odds, overall, seem to be rising.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Is It OK to Read a Newspaper Online When I’ve Stopped Paying for It?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether it’s fair to peek behind a publication’s paywall if you’re no longer a subscriber.
content: I canceled my digital subscription to a daily newspaper a couple of months ago, but the company still gives me total access to its content. Is it ethical to keep reading it? — Name Withheld
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Doug Mills and Carol Rosenberg
title: A Tent City Is Rising at Guantánamo Bay
description: These are the first independent images to emerge from the migrant operation that the Trump administration has begun at the Navy base.
content: The Trump administration has moved more than 30 people described as Venezuelan gang members to the U.S. Navy base at Guantánamo Bay, as U.S. forces and homeland security staff prepare a tent city for potentially thousands of migrants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Sept. 11 Plea Deal Includes Lifetime Gag Order on C.I.A. Torture Secrets
description: The clause is included in a disputed plea agreement between a Pentagon official and the man accused of planning the attacks that killed 3,000 people.
content: Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the prisoner at the military prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, who is accused of plotting the Sept. 11 attacks, has agreed to never disclose secret aspects of his torture by the C.I.A. if he is allowed to plead guilty rather than face a death-penalty trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: What DeepSeek? Big Tech Keeps Its A.I. Building Boom Alive.
description: An apparent breakthrough in efficiency from the Chinese start-up did not make tech’s biggest companies question their extravagant spending on new data centers.
content: Wall Street went into panic mode about two weeks ago after the Chinese start-up DeepSeek released an artificial intelligence system that appeared to be radically more efficient than what its American competitors had built.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Holmes
title: Worn Out by an Extrovert? You Can Go ‘Gray.’
description: Don’t engage an overbearing colleague — that is, be boring — and eventually the attention-seeker may give up and go away.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: It’s 3,500 Miles From Philadelphia. But for Eagles Fans, It Feels Like Home.
description: At Passyunk Avenue, a London bar founded by a Philadelphia transplant, the authentic touches go beyond cheesesteaks (but there are cheesesteaks).
content: Benjamin Franklin, the consummate colonial wanderer, once observed that home was not just a place, or a thing, or a food. “A house is not a home,” he said, “unless it contains fire for the mind, as well as the body.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman and Fatima AbdulKarim
title: Hamas Makes Gaunt Israeli Hostages Thank Captors Before Release
description: The scenes at the latest hostage release in Gaza angered Israelis and created even more uncertainty surrounding the next steps in a phased cease-fire deal.
content: Hamas released three Israeli hostages on Saturday in exchange for 183 Palestinians jailed by Israel, in a staged handover where rifle-toting Hamas fighters prodded their gaunt captives to give short speeches, effectively at gunpoint, thanking the militants who had held them captive for 16 months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson and Brian Kaiser
title: A Fishing Season That Lasts Just 17 Minutes
description: Despite its brevity, the rush to spear giant sturgeon in Cheboygan, Mich., is important to the local economy.
content: As fishing goes, the sturgeon spearing season on Black Lake may be the shortest in the country: Six fish long. Starting at 8 a.m. on Feb. 1, about 500 fishers hoped to throw spears at sturgeon passing under the ice until the sixth and final fish was caught 17 minutes later, the fastest season ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko and Qasim Nauman
title: Judge Halts Access to Treasury Payment Systems by Elon Musk’s Team
description: The order came in response to a lawsuit filed by 19 attorneys general accusing the president of failing to faithfully execute the nation’s laws when he let DOGE comb through federal computer systems.
content: A federal judge early Saturday temporarily restricted access by Elon Musk’s government efficiency program to the Treasury Department’s payment and data systems, saying there was a risk of “irreparable harm.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: As Ground Shifts, ‘Flailing’ Democrats Struggle to Find Footing in Diversity Fight
description: President Trump’s aggressive moves against transgender rights and diversity, equity and inclusion programs have left the Democratic Party casting about for a strategy for how to respond.
content: The Democratic Party is having an identity crisis about identity politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Aguilar
title: Karla Sofía Gascón Scandal Is Not the Only ‘Emilia Pérez’ Controversy
description: The actress’s old social media posts have threatened to derail the film’s Oscar campaign, but backlash has been building for months for other reasons.
content: When “Emilia Pérez” premiered at the prestigious Cannes Film Festival last May, the reaction from critics in attendance and the jury was overwhelmingly positive.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 2 Books for Anxious Minds
description: Nadine Gordimer’s stories; Margaret Atwood’s sketches.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: The U.S. Economy Is Racing Ahead As the Well-Being Of the Nation Lags
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, February 8, 2025
content: “We’re so wealthy but so unhappy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: 14 Unforgettable Looks at the Critics Choice Awards
description: Jellyfish gowns, Old Hollywood suits, tube tops and more.
content: The question of what celebrities will wear to an awards show always looms large before any ceremony. But it took on new significance ahead of the 30th Critics Choice Awards in Santa Monica, Calif., on Friday: After postponing the event twice because of the Los Angeles wildfires, organizers announced that a red-carpet preshow would not be part of the televised broadcast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yonette Joseph, Malika Khurana and Adam Pasick
title: Trump’s Foreign Aid Freeze Has Created Chaos. Here Is What to Know.
description: Critics say a Trump administration order calls into question the United States’ global standing and reliability.
content: President Trump’s executive order freezing most U.S. foreign aid for 90 days has thrown into turmoil programs that fight starvation and deadly diseases, run clinical trials and seek to provide shelter for millions of displaced people across the globe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight
title: Her Brother Disappeared in War 80 Years Ago. She Finally Got to Say Goodbye.
description: Margery Hop Wong last saw her older brother Sgt. Yuen Hop in 1943. He was a soldier missing in action, until researchers solved the mystery behind his death.
content: When Margery Hop Wong bade her older brother goodbye in 1943, she was just a 12-year-old girl who loved it when he took her for joy rides in his used convertible around the apple orchards their family worked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natan Odenheimer, Ephrat Livni, Talya Minsberg, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Lynsey Chutel
title: Here’s a Look at the 3 Israeli Hostages Freed Saturday
description: The release of the three men was the fifth in a staggered hostage-for-prisoner exchange laid out in a cease-fire deal between Hamas and Israel.
content: Hamas released three more Israeli hostages on Saturday as part of an exchange for Palestinian prisoners, in a highly theatrical handover in which the men were made to give speeches effectively at gunpoint.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: The Greatest ‘Saturday Night Live’ Episode Ever*
description: *Well, maybe only to me. “S.N.L.” fans all have their own idea of the show’s peak, and this is mine.
content: As measured by the calendar, “Saturday Night Live” is celebrating its 50th anniversary this year. But you could also say that 50 “Saturday Night Lives” are each celebrating an anniversary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: With Aid Cutoff, Trump Halts Agency’s Legacy of ‘Acting With Humanity’
description: Shock and grief rippled through the health community as lifelines for care were abruptly severed.
content: Funds from the world’s richest nation once flowed from the largest global aid agency to an intricate network of small, medium and large organizations that delivered aid: H.I.V. medications for more than 20 million people; nutrition supplements for starving children; support for refugees, orphaned children and women battered by violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: For Morris Chestnut, R&B Is Therapeutic
description: “It’s helpful in my work,” said the star of the new TV series “Watson,” “because it triggers thoughts, triggers memories, triggers emotions.”
content: When Morris Chestnut first heard about “Watson,” a new CBS medical mystery set within the Sherlock Holmes mythology, he was interested. But once he read the script by Craig Sweeny — the show’s creator and one of the writers behind that other Sherlockian CBS series, “Elementary” — he grew even more excited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Kate Moss, Christy Turlington and the New Calvin Klein
description: New York Fashion Week begins with a big debut.
content: There hasn’t been a Calvin Klein runway show in almost seven years. Calvin Klein himself has not attended a runway show for his brand in nearly two decades. But on Friday, the brand, now designed by Veronica Leoni, and Mr. Klein returned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian and Stephanie Nolen
title: U.S.A.I.D. Workers Brace for the Worst
description: A judge halted parts of the Trump administration’s plan to shut down the agency. A verdict might not come for weeks or even longer as thousands are left in limbo.
content: The thousands of people who work for the U.S. government’s main agency for humanitarian aid and disaster relief have been on the front lines of efforts to fight famine, contain virulent infectious diseases like H.I.V. and Ebola, and rebuild infrastructure in impoverished and war-torn countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan, Alan Feuer and Alexandra Berzon
title: Advocate of Jan. 6 Rioters Now Runs Office That Investigated Them
description: Ed Martin, a loyal Trump soldier, oversees the U.S. attorney’s office, which is likely to help turn the investigative powers of the government on several of the president’s perceived enemies.
content: Ed Martin was in the mob outside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, posting on social media that the violent riot that day was marked by “faith and joy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: How the Costume Designer for ‘Wicked’ Spends His Sundays
description: Paul Tazewell, who was nominated for an Oscar for “Wicked,” makes time for yoga before a day of shopping, museums and dinner with friends.
content: Paul Tazewell oversaw a staff of 140 as the costume designer for the movie version of the musical “Wicked.” In January, he was nominated for an Oscar for his work on the film, which included a gown for Ariana Grande that required 225 hours of work and 20,000 beads for the bodice. He also designed the suits worn by the movie’s computer-generated animals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyce McFadden, Nell Gallogly and Wesley Parnell
title: Amid Concern Over Trump Order, New Yorkers Rally to Support Trans Youth
description: Thousands of protesters in Union Square called for action against an executive order that threatens to withhold federal funding from hospitals that provide gender-affirming care.
content: Bells, drums and chants rang out Saturday afternoon in Union Square in Manhattan as thousands of New Yorkers gathered to protest an executive order from the Trump administration targeting transgender children and teens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: An Ankle Monitor? No, That’s My Apple Watch.
description: In pursuit of tracking fitness goals in a comfortable manner, a growing number of people are relocating their watches (and causing some confusion along the way).
content: In the old days, back when Ana Espinal was wearing an Apple Watch on her wrist at the gym, she often found that her fitness app would shut down during her workout. Ms. Espinal has tiny wrists, she said, and she wondered if the problem was her loose watch not being able to register her heart rate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Miller
title: Weight Loss, Love and Opening Up About It All
description: For an article about how weight-loss drugs affect marriage and intimacy, one health reporter worked with couples to “hold up a mirror to readers.”
content: Before I began reporting my article on how weight-loss drugs change the dynamics in romantic relationships, I asked my editors: Could we veil the identities of the main characters?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Otis
title: An Original Warhol, Carved From Potatoes
description: Illustrations by the artist, commissioned for The Times in 1962, were sculpted on spuds before being stamped onto paper.
content: In 1962, Andy Warhol, one of the 20th-century’s pre-eminent figures in Pop Art, produced some of what now are considered his signature works: “Gold Marilyn Monroe.” “Marilyn Diptych.” “Campbell’s Soup Cans.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Bullets and Barriers: How One City Is Trying to Reduce Gun Violence
description: Birmingham, Ala., which had a record year for homicides, is trying to curb shootings by blocking streets. But the effort has come to mean something else.
content: Bullets had already punctured the porch steps of Mel Aaron’s home in the East Lake neighborhood of Birmingham, Ala., one of the most violent cities in America. They had broken two windows. Once, they had narrowly darted past her teenage son’s head as he stood in the living room, again startled by the loud pops of a drive-by shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Capo, e.g.
description: Alina Abidi makes a sweet, smart Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is the first Saturday grid from Alina Abidi for The New York Times, and her second themeless after a recent Friday. I appreciate the lively touch here. We get a brisk workout, but the fill is unpretentious and charming, and it makes for a solve that flows along. Funny enough, every time I fell into a knowledge gap, there was a crossing entry involving a chef whose name I knew, or a familiar food or beverage, or the noises made by one of those foods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: The Agony of Adoring Online Dogs
description: With social media aging, so are the dogs that have for years filled our Instagram feeds with cheer. And when they die, the loss can be unexpectedly heart-wrenching.
content: Norbert was practically a stuffed animal come to life. The three-pound mixed-breed internet-famous therapy dog dispensed joy simply by existing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nazaneen Ghaffar and Judson Jones
title: Winter Storm Brings Heavy Snow to Northeast Before Moving Out
description: More than 10 inches of snow fell in parts of New England as snow, sleet and freezing rain swept across the Northeast before tapering off Sunday.
content: A winter storm delivered a steady mix of snow, sleet and freezing rain to the northeastern United States on Saturday but by Sunday the storm had moved offshore, leaving behind significant snowfall totals across the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Ambassador Tells Rubio U.S.A.I.D. Cuts Would Cause ‘Major Vulnerability’ in Africa
description: Other diplomats across the continent are sending similar cables to the secretary of state to try to maintain lifesaving aid programs on which millions of Africans depend.
content: The U.S. ambassador to Mozambique, Peter H. Vrooman, has sent an urgent cable to Secretary of State Marco Rubio saying that the forced withdrawal from Mozambique of all employees of the main U.S. aid agency would result in a “major vulnerability.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Harvey Araton
title: On Deadline at the Super Bowl, Remembering a Columnist’s Credo
description: Players aren’t the only ones under pressure as the game clock ticks down.
content: With another Super Bowl upon us, I’ve been thinking about the first one I covered, in 2004. At a staff dinner early in the week leading up to the game, Dave Anderson, my fellow Sports of the Times columnist, pulled me aside for a talk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Denzel Washington Has Finally Found His Purpose (It’s Not Acting)
description: The legendary actor discusses the prophecy that changed his life, his Oscar snub and his upcoming role starring alongside a “complicated” Jake Gyllenhaal in “Othello” on Broadway.
content: So many of Denzel Washington’s greatest performances — from the majestic title role in “Malcolm X” to the unrepentantly corrupt cop Alonzo Harris in “Training Day” — have been defined by a riveting sense of authority, an absolute absence of pandering or the need to be liked. There’s an inner reserve deep down inside his characters that is unassailable, a little enigmatic, and that belongs to them alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Trump Administration Cuts Put Medical Progress at Risk, Researchers Say
description: Grants from the National Institutes of Health come with additional money for overhead. A planned $4 billion cut would leave colleges with large budget gaps.
content: The nation’s universities and academic medical centers were reeling on Saturday from a directive by the Trump administration to slash funding for medical research, a decision that doctors and scientists said would have a devastating effect on studies aimed at finding treatments for diseases such as cancer, diabetes and heart disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: PlayStation Network Is Working After 24-Hour Outage, Sony Says
description: Users on social media had complained that they could not access their games after the unexplained outage began on Friday night.
content: The PlayStation Network, which users of the Sony PlayStation platform rely on to play games, download content and access apps, started working again on Saturday night after a 24-hour outage that left customers frustrated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Foreign Leaders Embrace the Art of Flattery in Wooing Trump
description: Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba is the latest figure to offer ample compliments to a president known for his transactional, if not unpredictable, approach to foreign policy.
content: Shortly after President Trump mused Friday over imposing tariffs on Japan while sitting alongside the country’s prime minister, Shigeru Ishiba, the Japanese leader was asked by a reporter to reflect on his first meeting with Mr. Trump. It was a prime opportunity to respond to Mr. Trump’s economic threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Passengers Restrain Man Who Bashed a Window on a Flight
description: The man broke the window’s inner pane and plastic frame before being subdued on a Frontier Airlines flight on Tuesday. The F.B.I. is investigating.
content: Chaos erupted aboard a Frontier Airlines flight from Denver to Houston this week when a man started bashing a window and several seats around him, prompting other passengers to subdue him with shoelaces and zip ties until the plane landed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laurel Rosenhall
title: Newsom Signs Bills to Fight Trump, Including Legal Aid for Immigrants
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom, a Democrat, has been balancing a desire to push back on Republican policies with a need to cooperate in seeking federal disaster aid.
content: Two days after meeting with President Trump at the White House to seek disaster aid, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California signed legislation on Friday that authorized $50 million in state funds intended to counter the president’s agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: U.S. Aid Agency’s Climate Programs Aimed to Curb Migration. Now They’re Gone.
description: Aid projects were designed to help Central Americans withstand extreme weather at home. Their end could undercut Trump’s goal of reducing  migration.
content: Two months ago, the Biden administration announced an initiative to share satellite data with Central American countries including Guatemala, Honduras and El Salvador to help them prepare for severe storms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and John Eligon
title: Trump Orders Halt to Aid to South Africa, Claiming Mistreatment of White Landowners
description: The president ordered that all foreign assistance to South Africa be halted and said his administration would prioritize the resettling of white, “Afrikaner refugees” into the United States.
content: President Trump on Friday ordered that all foreign assistance to South Africa be halted and said his administration would prioritize the resettling of white, “Afrikaner refugees” into the United States because of what he called actions by the country’s government that “racially disfavored landowners.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: During N.F.L. Games, Going to Commercial Requires Its Own Playbook
description: TV advertising is the lifeblood of the league, but knowing when to pause the games is a task undertaken by N.F.L. executives, network producers and on-field officials.
content: Television commercial breaks are the bane of every N.F.L. fan. They interrupt a game already riddled with stoppages, bombard viewers with come-ons and force fans and players in the stadium to stand around for about two and a half minutes, sometimes in the freezing cold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof and Dru Donovan
title: We Thought We Were Compassionate, but We Were Too Permissive
description: A friend’s journey through drugs and homelessness was aggravated by West Coast decriminalization. There’s a better path forward.
content: As a good liberal, I used to oppose arresting people for using drugs. They need health care, not handcuffs, I thought. But then to my surprise and dismay, I found myself praying that my old pal Drew Goff would be arrested.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Jimison
title: Democratic Lawmakers Denied Entry to the Department of Education
description: It was the fourth agency this week that federal employees blocked congressional Democrats from entering amid a push to shutter government agencies and dramatically cut the federal work force.
content: In a striking display of the limits being placed on congressional authority in the first weeks of the new administration, several Democratic lawmakers were denied entry to the U.S. Department of Education on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Dark Comedy
description: Movie audiences are cracking up during serious scenes. What’s a theatergoer to do?
content: There used to be a multiplex near my house that we called the “Babysitter 12” because it felt like, no matter the film on view, the theater was always full of people laughing, screaming, horsing around. I stopped going there after a while because while it was fun to be part of a boisterous crowd during, say, a Marvel movie, the constant din during more serious films grew distracting. The Babysitter 12 closed during the pandemic, when people’s living rooms became their theaters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shayla Colon and Sean Piccoli
title: Mother Is Charged in Death of Girl, 6, Who Was Found in Bathtub
description: The girl was unconscious when officers found her in a water-filled tub, officials said. Her mother was charged with assault.
content: A Brooklyn woman has been charged in the death of her 6-year-old daughter, who had been found unconscious on Friday in a bathtub filled with water, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yussef Cole
title: The Crises Are Simulations, but the Lessons Are Real
description: The turn-based strategy game Civilization VII emphasizes chaotic transition periods when latent challenges all emerge at once.
content: Unhappiness is a dreaded condition in the Civilization game series. Unhappy citizens stop working, stop researching scientific pursuits and, worst of all, start rioting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: What an Instagram Reel Has in Common With a 4-Hour Documentary
description: Humans love to watch other humans, whether it’s movies by Frederick Wiseman or vertical videos on your phone. In a way, we’re all documentarians.
content: Here is what I see when I scroll through Instagram Reels on my phone. A woman wakes up in bed, goes to the kitchen and pours coffee, inviting me to follow along with her morning routine. One swipe, and someone is making a “viral kale pasta Caesar salad.” Another swipe reveals a demonstration of “peel-and-stick stair treads,” which I can purchase on Amazon at the link in her bio. A man feeds a puppy a lemon wedge; it is not pleased. One of my own colleagues appears, explaining why we should start taking bird flu seriously.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: ‘We Are in Disbelief’: Africa Reels as U.S. Aid Agency Is Dismantled
description: The collapse of U.S.A.I.D. at the hands of President Trump and Elon Musk is already leaving gaping holes in vital health care and other services that millions of Africans rely on for their survival.
content: For decades, sub-Saharan Africa was a singular focus of American foreign aid. The continent received over $8 billion a year, money that was used to feed starving children, supply lifesaving drugs and provide wartime humanitarian assistance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Democrats Take Aim at Elon Musk
description: It’s the first sign of unified opposition for a rudderless and leaderless Democratic Party.
content: For eight years, Democrats saw Donald Trump as the most toxic brand in politics, a singular figure who unified their disparate factions and filled their political coffers with campaign contributions. The limits of that strategy became evident in November.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Political Future of Palestinians, According to Palestinians
description: Times Opinion spoke to five Palestinian scholars and analysts about what they believe the future holds for their people.
content: The Palestinian people have traveled a long and frustrating road to self-governance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Curses! A Swearing Expert Mulls the State of Profanity.
description: Timothy Jay, a scholar in the science of swearing, has a few choice words about why we curse and how to cut back (if you want to).
content: Cursing is coursing through society. Words once too blue to publicly utter have become increasingly commonplace. “Language is just part of the whole shift to a more casual lifestyle,” said Timothy Jay, a professor emeritus of psychology at the Massachusetts College of Liberal Arts in North Adams, Mass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Delaware Law Has Entered the Culture War
description: Elon Musk has helped bring an esoteric debate around the Delaware Chancery Court to a national stage. Now Dropbox and Meta are contemplating moving their incorporation away from the state.
content: The clubby insular world of corporate law has entered the culture war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Fact-Checking Claims About U.S.A.I.D. Funding
description: Trump administration officials have misled about how the aid agency is spending its funding, in an effort to cite widespread “waste.”
content: Top officials in the Trump administration and allies in Congress, eager to dismantle the U.S. Agency for International Development, have accused the agency of misusing taxpayer funds. But many of their claims were misleading or lacked context.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: What Happens to My Rent When the Building’s Tax Benefit Expires?
description: Once your apartment is no longer rent stabilized, there are laws that can protect you from eviction and unreasonable increases.
content: Q: We rent a market-rate unit in a building in Manhattan with 421-a benefits, which expire in July 2026. This has allowed us to enjoy the benefits of rent stabilization for a limited time. Our lease expires in March 2026, and our unit will no longer be under rent stabilization as of July 2026. Will we receive another rent-stabilized lease that March? Will it be for one year or two years? Once the 421-a benefits expire, will they simply not renew our leases, or change the rent to whatever they want?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: Springfield, Ohio, Sues Neo-Nazi Group, Saying It Intimidated Haitians
description: In the lawsuit, the city states that people associated with the group made death threats last year against those who expressed support for Haitian residents.
content: The city of Springfield, Ohio, which was singled out by Donald J. Trump and JD Vance during the presidential campaign with false and outrageous claims about Haitian immigrants, has sued a neo-Nazi group that helped draw national attention to the small city in the first place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Erik Fisher
title: The Price We Pay Betting on Sports
description: What sports betting reveals about addiction.
content: When we think about any addiction, we tend to focus on people who are utterly consumed by it — those whose lives are visibly falling apart. Yet gambling challenges our usual assumptions about addiction and risk, as its harms extend far beyond the most severe cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: A Trade War Is on Hold, but Trump’s Motives and a Fix Remain Uncertain
description: President Trump announced potentially crippling tariffs against Canada, only to suspend them for 30 days. What will satisfy him remains unknown.
content: When I returned to Windsor, Ontario, the day before President Trump was set to impose potentially devastating tariffs on exports from Canada, fear was the city’s prevailing mood. A week later, following Mr. Trump’s suspension of a 25 percent tariff on most exports and 10 percent on oil, the mood has shifted more toward anger and the nation’s focus has moved toward alternatives to the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Woman Arrested in Connection With Super Bowl Reporter’s Death
description: Adan Manzano, a reporter for Telemundo Kansas City, was found dead in a hotel room near New Orleans. A woman he was last seen with has been charged with stealing his credit card and phone.
content: A woman who has faced repeated allegations that she robbed men after drugging them was arrested Thursday in New Orleans in connection with the death one day earlier of a reporter for Telemundo Kansas City who was in town to cover the Super Bowl, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang and Cade Metz
title: How Sam Altman Sidestepped Elon Musk to Win Over Donald Trump
description: After helping President Trump get elected, Elon Musk was poised to dominate the country’s A.I. policies. Then Mr. Altman sneaked into the White House.
content: At President Trump’s inauguration, Sam Altman, the chief executive of OpenAI, was relegated to the overflow room while other tech billionaires like Elon Musk and Mark Zuckerberg took prime spots on the dais under the Capitol rotunda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: What’s It All About?
description: Rich Katz and Jeff Chen, constructors of great regard, team up on a Sunday challenge with twists and turns.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Elon Musk Wants
description: The journalist Kara Swisher discusses Elon Musk’s goals in government — and the factors that have led to his radicalization.
content: The journalist Kara Swisher discusses Elon Musk’s goals in government — and the factors that have led to his radicalization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By McKinnon de Kuyper
title: Three Israeli Hostages Are Released for 183 Palestinian Prisoners
description: Hamas released three Israeli hostages on Saturday in an exchange with Israel for more than 180 Palestinian prisoners, as part of a cease-fire deal.
content: Hamas released three Israeli hostages on Saturday in an exchange with Israel for more than 180 Palestinian prisoners, as part of a cease-fire deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac, Kate Conger, Christina Shaman, Gabriel Blanco, David Jouppi and Laura Salaberry
title: Elon Musk Brings His Playbook From Twitter to the Government
description: Ryan Mac and Kate Conger, two New York Times technology reporters who together wrote a book about what happened when Elon Musk bought Twitter, explain some of his tactics.
content: Ryan Mac and Kate Conger, two New York Times technology reporters who together wrote a book about what happened when Elon Musk bought Twitter, explain some of his tactics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nailah Morgan
title: House Democrats Denied Entry to the U.S. Department of Education
description: Several Democratic lawmakers attempted to access the department’s headquarters on Friday, after a request to meet with the acting education secretary went unanswered.
content: Several Democratic lawmakers attempted to access the department’s headquarters on Friday, after a request to meet with the acting education secretary went unanswered.
source.name: The New York Times
